qas.question: After the original Famicom sold out, what did the Japanese government do?
What event happened after the Yakuza noticed the sale of the original Famicom?

context: Designed by <a0_0>Masayuki Uemura<a0_0/>, the designer of the original Famicom, <b5_0>the Super Famicom<b5_0/> was released in Japan on Wednesday, November 21, 1990 for <a1_0><b7_0>¥25,000<a1_0/> (<a2_0>US$210<a2_0/>)<b7_0/>. It was an instant success; Nintendo's initial shipment of <a3_0><b6_0>300,000<a3_0/> units<b6_0/> sold out within hours, and the resulting <b9_0>social disturbance<b9_0/> led the Japanese government to <b8_0>ask video game manufacturers to schedule future console releases on weekends<b8_0/>. The system's release also gained the attention of <a4_0>the Yakuza<a4_0/>, leading to a decision to ship the devices at night to avoid robbery.
